comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: In the 1901 census, we have Mary Sheehan of the Drapery on the left of shot. She's still there in 1911.

comment.author: 60329026@N07
comment._content:
I'm not to surprised that this image drew little reaction when it was last posted as in my view it is possibly the work of a photographer in training or an amateur, as it contains many basic flaws in its composition. The goat has it's back to the camera, other than the scaffolding which Puck is standing on there is little foreground detail other than two children shading their eyes from a very bright sun which is lighting the left hand side of the street while the right hand side is partly in shade and a market stall obscures a lot of the detail in the lower left hand side while the banners going to the tower should be read from the other side. Shooting from the other side of the tower would have made a much better picture and a more experienced photographer would have waited until the sun was at a different angle and taken the shot from further down the street. An Ideal location would have been placing the camera on a window sill on one of the buildings further down the street. Why a window sill? plate cameras of the type used at this time were heavy bulky and usually mounted on a wooden tripod, film speeds were slow and even in bright sunlight as in this image shutter speeds could be down to about 1/10 (one tenth) of a second which would make it impossible to hand hold the camera also focusing and viewing was done on the back of the camera (no viewfinder) under a black cloth.  This shot would be the type of test that an apprentice would be sent out to photograph to see what they would return with, so as their employer could evaluate their camera craft. On reflection, I think what we are looking at here is an apprentice's work piece, simular to furniture makers apprentices making miniature pieces,
 
FYI I have worked as a photographer for 25 years mostly shooting B&W, still shooting but in a non professional capacity.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Further down on the left, Daniel Hayes, baker. Still listed as a baker in 1911, although he's 76 by then, Holy crap! In 1911 his wife Ellen is shown as having 15 children born, 4 living! She would have been born in 1841, and married in 1863 aged 22.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: On the right, D.J. Coleman is apparently Declan, shopkeeper. By 1911, it looks like DJs widow Julia has married Michael Foley. She has a 9 year old daughter, Nellie Coleman, and a 3 year old son, Timothy Foley. So, we can say this shop was probably not named DJ Coleman from 1907 on.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Datewise, the fair is held in August, these days August 10-12th. Wikipedia says the first day is a horse fair, and the second day a cattle fair.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Almost the Same Picture here is titled Puck Fair 1904 The picture is in the form as a Christmas and New Year Card. I say almost the same picture - see people around first 2 premises on the left there are slight differences. Carol you might also explain above (to your many non Irish fans) that the Puck is actually a Goat and yes the people of that part of Kerry actually have a fair over 3 days since 1613 (thats a date not a time for our new world readers) where the Puck is the Grand Marshal Next Year is the 400th year......

comment.author: 59302818@N00
comment._content: At least we now know that there was at one dry day in the Fair's History

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Pound and Pinfold are old words for a stray animal pen. A mulct (fine) had to be paid for their release. A bit like wheel clamping today. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinfold
